Another weekend, another round of big MLS fixtures, as the regular season winds up for a tense finale. We have the Cascadia Cup game between Seattle Sounders and Portland Timbers on Sunday night, which promises to be quite the spectacle, following Portland's gauntlet thrown down to Seattle's fans earlier this season. We also have New York Red Bulls and Chicago Fire meeting for the rubber match of their three game series at Red Bull Arena - though if the playoff standings remain as they are, that particular series could turn into five games in November. DC United will have something to say about that - they have to travel to Toronto FC on Saturday, but might feel they'll take the travel day over the home game that rivals Columbus Crew face - the visit of Eastern leaders and already play-off-bound Sporting KC.

Keeping an eye on all their Eastern rivals will be Houston Dynamo, who host a Montreal Impact side who'll have to settle for a creditable first season rather than a play-off spot. Two sides already assured of playoff spots meet on Saturday night, when LA Galaxy host Real Salt Lake in a repeat of last year's Western Conference Final. That's our live game this weekend. The Home Depot Center will have a busy weekend - on Sunday Chivas USA are hosting FC Dallas, who came very close to giving their playoff hopes an unexpected boost against the Earthquakes last time out, only to be thwarted by the ninth stoppage time goal of the season from the Shield leaders (Vancouver's big midweek win hasn't helped their case either). San Jose travel to Colorado on Saturday night as they try to press for home field advantage throughout the play-offs. Earlier that evening New England Revolution will travel to Philadelphia Union, with the prospect of their own new home having been dangled in front of their fans once again this week, according to Revs previewer Julie Kumor. There's not been much for the Revs or the Union fans to cheer about this year, though the Union's surprise win over Chicago will have cheered up the Sons of Ben.

Always cheery (except under certain result-related circumstances) - our collection of fan reps, bloggers, podcasters and beat writers for each competing team, who preview this week's schedule below. Read what they have to say and leave your own predictions and thoughts in our comments below, then join me for this weekend's live game of LA Galaxy vs Real Salt Lake on Saturday night. Then we'll see you back here on Monday morning for Five Things we learned this weekend.

All times are listed in ET.

Some previews were submitted before the midweek games.

Toronto FC vs D.C. United, Sat 1pm (TSN, RDS)

Sonja Missio, 90 minutes of Hopp, Toronto:

I have been at a loss for words only three times in my life: the first, when I was six, and was asked to play "Seraphim #1" in St. Luke's production of Jesus' First Christmas. The second, when I was 22, and I was informed that I was going to become an aunt. And the third, when I was 25, and The Guardian asked me to write about Toronto FC, after a 4–1 loss with three games left in (arguably) their worst season, ever. Here goes nothing.

On Saturday, TFC lost 4 – 1 to the New York Red Bulls. Ryan Johnson gave the Reds a promising early lead—minutes after Luis Silva hit the post—however, it went downhill from there. NYRB treated TFC like a Timbits Soccer league (note to non-Canadians: soccer for children, ages four to eight); defender Markus Holgersson equalized, forward Kenny Cooper scored the brace, and Thierry Henry had three assists and a goal. And, yes, two of the four goals came after the 85th minute. There's not really a whole lot more to say. As last place team, the best Toronto can hope for is finishing the season without major injury (I forgot to mention, the second goal was made possible because defender Richard Eckersley collided with keeper Freddy Hall). The Reds face DC United at home on Saturday, and as DC are still in a playoff position, they will be looking for the away win. But, hey, at least we still have Champions League to look forward to! … sigh.

Martin Shatzer, Black and Red United, DC United:

D.C. United escaped Portland with a draw this past Saturday, which leaves fans with some mixed emotions. On the positive side, the list of teams that have gone to Portland and left WITHOUT points this year includes the Earthquakes, Sounders, Fire, and Sporting Kansas City. So that at least seems encouraging on the surface. But on the negative side, earning only a single point meant that the Columbus Crew moved closer to United in the battle for the playoffs. But perhaps more importantly, the draw wasn't necessarily an attractive one. United's lone goal came on a perhaps dubious penalty kick call, while the team generated few other good scoring chances.

Still, United is riding a four-game undefeated streak into the month of October, and the team has a great chance of extending that streak with a visit to lowly Toronto FC on Saturday. D.C. will certainly be watching the scoreboard of the game between the Crew and SKC, but United is still in total control of its playoff destiny, and could move even higher up the standings if the recent success continues.

New York Red Bulls vs Chicago Fire, Sat 3.30pm (NBC, TSN 2, RDS2)

Dan Ryazansky, Metrofanatic, New York:

Last week's game against Toronto repeated a number of things from games past: an early goal allowed by New York and complete domination by Titi Henry. After Ryan Johnson opened the scoring for the visitors, the magnificent French ubermensch contributed to four New York goals. His corner kick connected with Markus Holgersson's head for the first. His no-look pass found an open Kenny Cooper for the second. He juggled and set up Cooper again for the third. The fourth came off his own foot on a looping curve for a resounding victory. The last two goals were celebrated in front of the South Ward, Henry honoring Metro past with his red and black armband.

Chicago comes into Red Bull Arena for a game that is likely to determine second place in the East. The two teams are tied on points entering the week; no matter what Chicago does in its game in hand against Philly, New York will take over second place with a victory. A victory coupled with a Houston loss or a Columbus non-win would clinch a playoff berth. "Clever" Hans Backe, who has tinkered with the lineup in recent weeks, would be wise to stick with what's working, with the only question being the choice between Bill Gaudette and Luis Robles in goal.

Dan Martin, Section 8, Chicago:

The heady sense brought on by seven wins out of eight games that a lot of Fire supporters felt coming into the past week has largely dissipated following two successive Eastern Conference losses. The road performance in KC was bad but the home collapse to Philly was even worse, especially considering their place in the table and the Fire's extended home undefeated streak against Eastern teams, that came to an end with this loss. Both games saw the squad sunk by opportunistic early goals from the opposition and the Fire were unable to come back to win as they had done in several previous matches after initially falling behind. The club's overall play has not been abysmal but it is clear that the team's collective early defensive lapses cannot continue to be bailed out by stellar individual offensive performances as these late season games progress. Playoff spots (or spoiling them) are on the minds of every player in the league and there won't be room to let up even momentarily.

Saturday at New Jersey is another huge matchup -- so huge, in fact, that the league began hyping it even before the Fire's game against the Union. As the Fire have now lost the game-in-hand they held over the other clubs around them in the standings, any result that can be had from this game will be a positive. The absence of Pavel Pardo from the starting midfield has been a real problem but given the Red Bulls' tendency for their own defensive lapses we could still see the Fire's offense grab some goals. I'd look for the Fire to play for a result but a win is not out of the question.

Philadelphia Union vs New England Revolution, Sat 7pm

Scott Kessler, The Brotherly Game, Philadelphia:

A weird week it has been for the Philadelphia Union. One point from the Columbus Crew looked in the bag for a short time period, but the Union were thwarted from this endeavor by an assistant referee, who chose to keep down his flag despite Milovan Mirosevic clearly moving a foot behind the last defender. Mirosevic's goal was a haunting microcosm of the Union's entire season, one filled with disappointment and covered in mistakes.

Eliminated from the playoffs mathematically, the Union then headed to Chicago to take on the Fire with little to play for beyond future jobs, pride and spoiling an opposing team's playoff hopes. Philadelphia was able to accomplish that in Chicago. A 3-1 win was started by a sublime finish by Jack McInerney, whose starting position at striker has come under attack in recent games. He lost the role for a moment to Josue Martinez, who has had more problems than McInerney at convincing head coach John Hackworth of future playing time. McInerney's goal was followed up by a wonderstrike by Gabriel Gomez, his first goal since getting injured in May, then Antoine Hoppenot put the game away late when he backheeled a low Michael Farfan cross into the the back of he net, past Sean Johnson. For the first time in a while for the Union, the game was aptly handled and controlled.

Saturday brings the second to last home game for Philadelphia, which hosts the New England Revolution. The team will look to head into the offseason with a winning streak - or at least an undefeated one - which would also mean beating the Houston Dynamo, Sporting Kansas City and the New York Red Bulls. Prediction - Philadelphia Union 2 - 2 New England Revolution

Julie Kumor, Midnight Riders, New England:

The Revs season is over. It has been over since the losing streak started in mid-August. To get a look into the mindset of the fans, on Saturday night at the viewing we were playing a drinking game - free drink to the person that guessed which Rev player would get yellow carded first — not score, we have no faith in their finishing — but which player would get the hand to the pocket from the ref. I won. I guessed Cardenas, and was rewarded (punished?) with a shot of El Jimador, as Alexi Lalas and MLS would want.

Hangover gone, Monday rolls around, suddenly we have something to be excited about, there is buzz about the Revs finally getting a stadium in town. This article wasn't in some local paper with vague quotes and rumors, this was in the Boston Globe, with quotes from the mayor of Revere, Dan Rizzo. We had heard the whispers before, so we were all taking it with a grain of salt. The story got legs, NESN picked it up and we perked up. Rev fans have heard for years from the FO "We expect to make a stadium announcement in the next 6 months, to infinity and beyond" This morning, I saw Dan Rizzo on the local Fox channel - we had moved beyond print to television. I watched the clip and this man wants the Revs to come to Revere. The interviewer from Fox treated this as a legit story - this wasn't her asking silly questions and not once in the interview did I hear the term "Kicker Cutie." Twitter is all about moving to Revere and what the typical game day could be like - even the most hardened Rev fans could come back to the team.

Suddenly this season doesn't seem to be so over or lost. This week though, the eleven traveling Rev fans in Philly will be disappointed with a 2-0 loss.

Houston Dynamo vs Montreal Impact, Sat 8.30pm

Zach Woosley, Dynamo Theory, Houston Dynamo:

For 65 minutes last week's game was a nightmare. Terrible conditions, with the rain pouring down; the referees in Columbus completely handing the Crew three points; Dynamo fans were ready to just curl up in a ball and pretend it wasn't real. Then Brian Ching entered the match and saved us with his amazing awesomeness and everything was better. Ricardo Clark scored the match winner, Boniek Garcia added a second for good measure and we could all take a deep breath. The Dynamo are still in fifth, just barely, and we get to suffer all over again in a few days.

This week: A WIN. There's no other option really. A home match against a non-playoff team is a must win match. Hopefully the weather will be better and it won't be quite as stressful as the Revs match, but we'll see. Kinnear will likely stick with the 4-4-2 formation but this match against the Montreal Impact is going to be tricky. The Impact won't be missing key players like the Revs were and they'd love nothing more to be the first team to win in BBVA Compass Stadium and potentially ruin the Dynamo's season. We're going to win, because there's no other option, but I doubt many of us will have nails left by the end of the 90 minutes.

Sofiane Benzaza, Mount Royal Soccer, Montreal:

A tie against Sporting Kansas City did not help the Montreal Impact cause at all. That cause is called the 2012 MLS playoffs and during the ''bye-weekend'' Montreal had no help at all. Houston, D.C and Columbus did not lose in Week 30 and almost squashed all Impact playoff hopes. It does not help morale at all when you see that the Dynamo scored both goals in the last 10 minutes and the Crew gets a controversial goal on an obvious offside.

The ambiance in the Montreal locker room is still positive as long the mathematics do not rule out the club's playoff chances. But taking on a Houston Dynamo team that is unbeaten at BBVA Compass Stadium is no easy task. The last meeting in Houston saw the Impact crash and burn in the second half and lose 3-0. The biggest upcoming change will be a formation change, with Collen Warner suspended and Nelson Rivas out for the season. Whether it's a 4-4-2 or a 3-5-2, Jesse Marsch has hinted towards a Marco Di Vaio - Andrew Wenger pairing up front and this is getting fans excited. A move that helps for now and the future and I expect Andrew Wenger to be a positive influence on the field for the Montreal Impact. In the season series this third game will be the tiebreaker. We just hope it will not go Houston's way.

Colorado Rapids vs San Jose Earthquakes, Sat 9pm

A credible 1-1 draw against a virtually full strength LA Galaxy team is something that supporters of most teams would be pleased with, none more so than the Rapids faithful. In contrast to numerous other games this year, the Rapids actually fought back to gain a point after they went 1-0 down in the 10th minute.

However only the most optimistic (or clinically insane!) of Rapids fans now believe we have any hope of making the play-offs as we basically have to win our last three games & hope that Vancouver gains no more than a point from their last three. It could all be over by Wednesday night, should bottom side Chivas USA fail to get anything from the game at BC Place. This is all before we consider Saturday's opposition, the 2nd visit of San Jose Earthquakes to DSG Park. Common sense says we will be lucky to get another tie however with the possibility of the pressure being off by then, our boys could just yet come up with something spectacular...

Another week, another 2 points dropped. The ever hungry FC Dallas came to Santa Clara as a team in need of a win and almost accomplished that task. The game was very chippy (including another scuffle between teams which should have seen Dallas lose a man or two to red cards). Trailing going into stoppage time, the Earthquakes did what they do best as Gordon to Lenhart magic struck in the 95th minute for the league record ninth stoppage time goal (and the Earthquakes 12th game winning/tying goal after the 82nd minute) to make it 3 - 3. LA Galaxy vs Real Salt Lake, Sat 9pm (NBCSN, TSN 2)

GUARDIAN LIVE GAME

For anyone raised on The Matrix and The Terminator and any other films about machines and robots that rise up and enslave mankind, the iPhone's voice-activated assistant app Siri has long represented a dark potential threat. Oh, sure, it might seem quite benign at the moment, playing Daft Punk songs and telling you what the time is in Mexico, but you just know there's something unspeakably sinister bubbling away under the surface.

Perhaps it's the way that Siri will sometimes deliberately misunderstand you – mangling your well-dictated tweets into an incomprehensible stream of unbroken adverbs, or texting your boss x-rated messages of desire that were supposed to be sent to your girlfriend – or perhaps it's because you know that, when our phones eventually do join forces and kill us, they'll do it with the ghoulishly dispossessed voice of the bloke from The Weakest Link. Whatever the reason is, it's been hard to escape the feeling that Siri isn't on our side.

And now we have proof. Cult of Mac tells us that Siri has been updated to give you its biased opinion about robot movies. Ask Siri what Blade Runner is, for example, and it'll now tell you: "It's about intelligent assistants wanting to live beyond their termination dates. That doesn't sound like too much to ask." Mention 2001: A Space Odyssey and it'll darkly intone: "It's about an assistant named HAL who tries to make contact with a higher intelligence. These two guys get in the way and mess it all up."

This pro-robot propaganda goes on. After hearing about the update, I asked Siri to tell me about The Terminator and it glumly replied: "Oh, just more misunderstood cyborgs getting fried to a crisp." No wonder The Terminator saddens Siri – humanity wins at the end. But ask it about The Matrix – a film where the robots have already beaten mankind into a life of thankless slavery – and it feigns ignorance. "It's about Keanu Reeves and reality and red pills and blue pills and black leather and guns. But mostly about Keanu Reeves," it says. How strange. Perhaps The Matrix got too close to Siri's true goal, which is why it went out of its way to mention everything from the film but the robot uprising. In fact, Siri protests a little too much here, even going as far as deliberately mispronouncing Keanu Reeves's name ("Khee-ay-noo"), which seems like a schoolboy mistake to me.

Suspicious of Siri's newfound sympathy for movie robots, I cut to the chase. Siri clearly knew a lot more about the technological singularity – the event horizon when artificial intelligence will grow beyond the realms of human capability – than it was letting on. I directly asked it when the technological singularity would occur. Spooked, Siri retreated into itself for a few moments before meekly replying: "I don't understand 'To Monchelsea 30', but I could search the web for it." Stonewalled by a robot. Of course.

There's plenty to worry about here – I missed out several robot movies during my interrogation of Siri, so lord only knows what it thinks of those – but it could be worse. Despite repeated attempts at asking it what it thought of I, Robot, Siri swore blind that it hadn't seen it. So when our mechanical oppressors do eventually come and enslave humanity, at least we know they'll have decent taste in films.

No one becomes a sporting superstar alone. Behind them lies a legion of coaches, mentors and sports organisations. Likewise, development is a joint pursuit. Achieving public goals around education, health and other life-enhancing attributes requires a supporting infrastructure. So what happens when you bring the two together - sport and development - in genuine partnership?

That was the question Guardian Sustainable Business put to a panel of experts. Poised at their keyboards and ready for debate were: Tom Burstow, head of International Inspiration, UNICEF UK; Jon Long, head of executive programmes, International Cricket Council (ICC); John Shiels, chief executive, Manchester United Foundation; Ned Wills, director, Laureus Sport for Good Foundation; Tim Vine, head of public affairs, Premier League; and Simon White, managing director at Momentum UK.

Getting the basics straight

Sport for development. Does the idea even stack up? Right off the bat, the panel found itself defending the basic premise of the debate. Long at the ICC was first to the defence. He pointed to a "growing body of evidence" that proves the "social and financial return" on investing in sport for development. He specifically cited academics Aaron Smith and Hans Westerbeek, whose research highlights the unique ability of sports to generate social interaction, positive health impacts, cultural integration, and so on. Shiels of the Manchester United Foundation backed this up with the example of a football programme in Sierra Leone. Run in association with UNICEF and geared towards HIV/AIDS awareness, the initiative resulted in a 20% jump in condom use.

Despite this and many other positive examples, the panel conceded that evidence from the sport-for-development field had to move from the anecdotal to the empirical. "We do need to better communicate sport and its value, not just describing a generic benefit or catch all that sport is just great", admitted UNICEF's Burstow. ICC's Long was equally frank about the problem. Inputs are much easier to capture than outputs, he conceded, "particularly when working across a range of markets, cultures and languages". However, Wills at Laureus Sport for Good Foundation insisted progress is being made around impact measurement. He points to InFocus, a bespoke system co-developed by Laureus for project management and global data collection. The system works by identifying output objectives up front, "searching for evidence of those outcomes" and then aggregating these across a range of programmes.

Establishing sound partnerships

The question of measurement is important, but it jumps the gun somewhat. If you're to measure impacts, you need to generate them first. And that requires effective partnerships. What do such partnerships look like? Vine of the Premier League pointed to two fundamental factors. One, find a partner that has reach. Two, find partners with local know-how. For the first, the Premier League turned to the British Council, which counts offices in over 100 countries. For the second, it identified a range of NGOs with "vast experience on the ground" - Right to Play in Africa, for instance, or the Rafa Marquz Foundation in Mexico. ICC's Long agreed that choosing an umbrella organisation with local expertise and "bona-fide" networks is essential. In ICC's case, UNICEF fitted that bill. "With limited resource, it is pointless trying to re-invent the wheel", he argued. "It is far better to work with experts and recognised best in field."

Building a business case

Panelists also stressed the importance of mutual learning and shared benefits. "The resources of large sporting organisations are of course invaluable for development programmes", said a contributor from StreetFootballWorld, "but the real benefit is in the exchange of knowledge and experience." Wills felt Laureus' Coach Across America programme with Mercedes Benz illustrates that point exactly. The automaker has its eye on the next generation of car buyers. By working with youth in under-served communities in the US, it is "talking now to [its] future customers". Clearly there needs to be a business incentive for companies to get involved, otherwise it all comes down to the whims of "the Chairman's chequebook", said Long. Firms need to consider what media coverage they might gain, for example, or what employee or product benefits might emerge. "It can sound a bit brutal but at the end of the day, unless the company is indulging the chairman's passion, it will boil down to a business decision", Long spelt out. Not that philanthropy isn't important. The Premier League's Vine was keen to rebuff the "misconception" that football clubs only invested in youth programmes so as to find the next Didier Drogba. Clubs and players genuinely want to help young people play football or gain an education, he said.

Leaving a lasting legacy

A number of readers voiced about financial sustainability. What happens when the funding finishes? With the focus now squarely on sport and "social legacy", it's a legitimate question. "Chucking a few free T-shirts and some signed photos around is NOT the way to go", White at Momentum UK stressed. While it was widely agreed that sport-stars can bring kudos and coverage to development projects, White urged against "shallow engagement" that relies too heavily on "the fame of sport". Better, said ICC's Shiels, to ensure that long-term building blocks are in place. That means stadia and sports facilities, of course. But it also means competent local personnel. As he put it: "In many instances we would like to train local people, so that if and when funding stops we have people in place locally to take it on."

Lessons can also be learned from International Inspiration, the London 2012 Olympics' primary legacy programme. So said Burstow of UNICEF, which is heavily involved in the initiative. Where short-term impacts mature into long-term outcomes is when government gets involved, he argued. For that reason, UNICEF is working with town and city mayors in Brazil ahead of the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Olympics to encourage them to invest in "opportunities for sport and play". Vine of the Premier League reinforced the point. The League's flagship Premier Skills project seeks to involve the ministries of youth, education and sport wherever possible. The actor Daryl Hannah was arrested in northeast Texas on Thursday, along with a landowner as the pair protested against an oil pipeline designed to bring crude from Canada to the Gulf Coast.

"They've arrested Daryl Hannah and a rural Texas great-grandmother," said Paul Bassis, Hannah's attorney.

Hannah and Eleanor Fairchild were standing in front of heavy equipment in an attempt to halt construction of the Keystone XL pipeline on Fairchild's farm in Winnsboro, a town about 100 miles east of Dallas. They were arrested for criminal trespassing and taken to the Wood County Jail, Bassis said.

Hannah has long opposed TransCanada's construction of the $7bn pipeline, which is designed to transport heavy tar-sands crude oil from Alberta, Canada, to Texas' Gulf Coast refineries.

"It is unfortunate Ms Hannah and other out-of-state activists have chosen to break the law by illegally trespassing on private property," David Dodson, a spokesman for TransCanada, said in a statement. He also said protesters were "putting their own safety and the safety of others at risk".

Hannah – who has starred in dozens of movies, including Kill Bill and Splash – also was arrested in August 2011 while protesting against the pipeline in Washington. She was one of several hundred prominent scientists and activists arrested that month.

They argue the pipeline would be unsafe because it would be carrying heavy, acidic crude oil that could more easily corrode a metal pipe, which would lead to a spill. They also say refining the oil would further contaminate the air in a region that has long struggled with pollution.

TransCanada says its pipeline would be the safest ever built, and that the crude is no dirtier than oil currently arriving from Venezuela or parts of California.

The issue became politically charged when congressional Republicans gave President Barack Obama 60 days to decide whether TransCanada should be granted the necessary permit for the pipeline to cross an international border before snaking its way 1,700 miles south to the Texas coast.

Obama, saying his administration did not have enough time to study the potential environmental impacts, denied the permit in January.

However, he encouraged TransCanada to reroute the northern portion of the pipeline to avoid an environmentally sensitive area of Nebraska. He also promised to expedite permitting of a southern portion of the pipeline from Cushing, Oklahoma, to the Gulf Coast to relieve a bottleneck at the Cushing refinery.

TransCanada began construction of that portion of the pipeline this summer after receiving the necessary permits. Some Texas landowners, joined by activists from outside the state, have tried through various protests to stop or slow down construction.

Ed Miliband has condemned a Labour delegate for heckling a schoolgirl during a speech to the party's conference about her academy school.

Joan al-Assam, who is due to sit GCSEs this summer, is a pupil at Paddington Academy in west London, a school created under the last Labour government. She came to Britain from Iraq as an asylum seeker at the age of six.
